Asking Forensics Questions So you are looking at some piece of evidence. Evidence could be anything from a website, to an image, to even simply a piece of text.

item.title: Ciphers
item.description: Substitution Ciphers What is a Substitution Cipher? A Substitution cipher is a way of encrypting data, where every occurrence of specific letter from the alphabet within the plaintext you supply, is substituted by another character from the alphabet.

item.title: Crypto Intro
item.description: Cryptography is the practice of securing communication from third-party access, ensuring that only the intended recipient can access the message. It involves the use of mathematical algorithms to encode and decode information, converting it into a secret code that is unreadable to anyone except the intended recipient.

item.title: Encoding
item.description: ASCII ASCII or the American Standard Code for Information Interchange is an encoding scheme designed to represent simple text characters on computers.

item.title: Encryption
item.description: Encryption v.s Encoding Encryption and encoding are often confused. Encoding is a way to convert data from one format to another.

item.title: Forensics Intro
item.description: Forensics is the art of recovering the digital trail left on a computer. There are plently of methods to find data which is seemingly deleted, not stored, or worse, covertly recorded.

item.title: Hashing
item.description: What is Hashing? Hashing is a super neat example of cryptography, with many important uses in data integrity. The algorithm used when hashing takes any input data (known as the plaintext) - such as a message, a file, a password - and produces a fixed size ciphertext; which is a hash value, most commonly referred to has a hash.

item.title: Linux Intro
item.description: What is Linux? Linux is an operating system, just like Windows or Mac OS. It is a free and open source operating system, meaning that anyone can use it, modify it, and distribute it.

item.title: Programming Intro
item.description: Programming is a vast field, and there are many different languages and tools that can be used to solve challenges. In this section, we will learn about the basics of programming, and how to use the programming tools that are used in CTFs.

item.title: Solving MCPSHSF on a Chromebook
item.description: Although it is possible to solve MCPSHSF challenges on a Chromebook, it is difficult. This is because Chromebooks do not support the use of virtual machines, which are necessary for solving many challenges.

item.title: What are file formats?
item.description: File Extensions are not the sole way to identify the type of a file, files have certain leading bytes called file signatures which allow programs to parse the data in a consistent manner.

item.title: What is a hex editor?
item.description: A hexadecimal (hex) editor (also called a binary file editor or byte editor) is a computer program you can use to manipulate the fundamental binary data that constitutes a computer file.

item.title: What is disk imaging?
item.description: A forensic image is an electronic copy of a drive (e.g. a hard drive, USB, etc.). It’s a bit-by-­bit or bitstream file that’s an exact, unaltered copy of the media being duplicated.

item.title: What is memory forensics?
item.description: There are plenty of traces of someone’s activity on a computer, but perhaps some of the most valuble information can be found within memory dumps, that is images taken of RAM.

item.title: What is metadata?
item.description: Metadata is data about data. Different types of files have different metadata. The metadata on a photo could include dates, camera information, GPS location, comments, etc.

item.title: What is steganography?
item.description: Stegonagraphy is the practice of hiding data in plain sight. Stegonagraphy is often embedded in images or audio. You could send a picture of a cat to a friend and hide text inside.

item.title: What is wireshark?
item.description: Wireshark is a network protocol analyzer which is often used in CTF challenges to look at recorded network traffic. Wireshark uses a filetype called PCAP to record traffic.
